sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para:
&app; is a feature-rich user backup program with a simpe, intuitive interface. It offers the following features:
Each user of the system can configure their own backups
Automated backups for groups of files and folders with backup sets
On-demand backups
A tray icon to monitor the current progress of backups or restore operations
Several backup engines including compression and incremental backups
Support for backing up to a remote host via SSH/SFTP
Support for restoring any of the backups created with &app;

sect2.title: Starting &app;
sect2.para: There are two ways to start &app;:

listitem.para:
Select
System Preferences &app;
To start &app; from the command line, type &app; and press Return.

tip.para: More options are available! Type &app; --help and then press Return to see all the available options.

sect2.title: Once &app; has started
sect2.para: Once &app; has started, you are presented with the overview page. To begin using &app;, either click a toolbar button to switch pages or select an option from the menu. Below are short descriptions of each page:

listitem.para: The Overview page itself serves no purpose at the moment, but in future releases it will include detailed statistics about backup runs.
The Backup Sets page allows you to create, edit or remove backup sets as well as run a backup of a set on demand.
The One-Time Backup page configures and runs one-time backups.
The Log Viewer page displays the contents of the &app; log file (stored at ~/.&app;/&app;-userlog.txt).
All log messages are formatted like this: Month DD HH:MM:SS :: severity : message
Messages from previous sessions are colored in purple
Messages from the current session are colored in blue
Errors and warnings are colored in red and yellow respectively
The Restore page allows you to restore any backups created with &app;.

sect2.title: Creating a new set
sect2.para: To create a new set, click the Backup Sets button on the toolbar to switch pages. Next, click the New Set button on the left.
You'll find that the set configuration dialog has a set name text entry plus five tabs:

sect3.title: Paths
sect3.para: Use the controls on the left to select which files or folders (paths) you would like to back up. A green icon beside a path means that you are able to read it, while a red icon indicates you are unable to read the path and it will be excluded from the backup.

tip.para: Adding files or folders is as easy as dragging them from your favourite file manager and droping them onto the path list.

sect3.title: Destination
sect3.para: The destination tab controls where your backup will be written to. You may choose to backup to a local drive, to a removable drive or to a remote computer which supports the SFTP protocol (such as those running the OpenSSH server).

warning.para: Be sure to click the Test Settings button before saving your set! Although all settings look complete in the example configuration below, the password could have been entered incorrectly and as a result, all subsequent backups would fail.

sect3.title: Times
sect3.para: This tab controls the time and date at which the backup should be started at. Both easy configuration and manual configuration methods are supported. Using the manual entry is not recommended for most users.

sect4.title: Times (Easy configuration)
sect4.para: The easy configuration is controlled by using the drop-down boxes, and sliders to determine at which time &app; should schedule a backup. A backup of the set is run whenever the date matches the chosen parameters.

sect4.title: Times (Manual configuration)
sect4.para: The fields in a crontab must follow this format:

&app; can handle interfacing with the crontab, however in manual configuration mode you must supply (valid) values for the first five fields. The sixth field, used for the command, is generated automatically by &app;.

To use manual configuration, simply enter the same values you would into a crontab into the designated entry boxes. Please note that you cannot enter all five fields onto one line; The four fields are divided among four different entry boxes.

listitem.para: Use a comma (,) to specify a list of values
Use a dash (-) to specify a range of values
Use an asterisk (*) to specify all possible values

example.title: Using an asterisk
example.para: * in the hours field is the same as 0-23 or 1,2,3,4,5,6,[...],23

listitem.para: Most variants of cron support the forward slash (/) to designate a skip

example.title: Using a forward slash
example.para: */2 in the minutes field is equivalent to 0,2,4,6,8,[...],58

listitem.para: In the day of the week field, both 0 and 7 are counted as Sunday.
If both day of month and day of week are present, the command will be executed when either is true.

sect3.title: Options (Simple & Advanced)
sect3.para: The Options (Simple) and Options (Advanced) tabs include useful parameters about your backup. In addition, the options tabs allow you to you select the backup engine and the number of old backups to keep at any given time.

tip.para: Please see the Backup Options section for a detailed description of the options presented in these tabs.

sect2.title: Editing an existing set
sect2.para: To edit a set, click the Backup Sets button on the toolbar to switch pages and select the desired set. Next, click the Edit Set button to reconfigure the set. You can configure existing sets the same way you configure a new set (see here).

sect2.title: Running a backup only once
sect2.para: The One-Time Backup page configures and runs one-time backups. Similar to configuring sets, add files to a one-time backup using the buttons on the left and then click the Next button. Once you have selected your backup options, click Start Backup to begin the operation.
If you are looking for information on the various backup options, please see the Backup Options section for a more detailed description.

sect2.title: Restoring backups
sect2.para: The Restore page gives access to restore operations from either a set backup, an external archive or an external folder.

listitem.para: This entry defines where the files should be restored to. To the make selection more convienient, a Browse... button is available. As with the backup paths, a green icon indicates that the folder entered is writable and a red icon indicates that the folder is unwritable and another must be chosen.

tip.para: Setting this to root directory (/ on *nix platforms) or the root drive (typically C:\ on the Windows platform) will restore your files to their original locations.

listitem.para: A restore operation can be performed from various sources:
A set's backup on date YYYY-MM-DD
An external archive (a one-time backup using the tar engines with or without compression)
A folder (a one-time backup using the rsync engine)
A folder or archive on a remote computer (via SFTP)

sect3.title: Importing Sets
sect3.para: To import set configuration files (.conf files), select File Import Sets and then select the .conf file(s) to be imported. Any version of the &app; configuration files can be imported.

tip.para: The location at which set configurations are stored is ~/.&app;/Sets/.

sect3.title: Exporting Sets
sect3.para: To export set configurations, select FileExport Sets .
Simply check the sets you would like to export and choose a folder to export their configurations to.

sect1.title: Backup Options

textobject.phrase: Shows the One-Time Backup configuration page

sect1.para: Below is a description of the various backup options for both set and one-time backups.

listitem.para: This checkbox only applicable to backup sets: One-time backups must remain enabled otherwise they will not run properly
If checked, sparse files will be handled more efficiently

warning.para: Checking this can cause your backup to fail in some cases - do not enable it unless you are sure.

listitem.para: Sets whether or not the backup operation should recurse into subfolders
If checked, hidden files -files starting with a period character, . - are included in the backup.

varlistentry.term: Print installed packages to a text file

listitem.para: If checked, installed RPM package's names and versions will be printed to a text file in aim to easy recovery in the unfortunate event of a system crash

varlistentry.term: Print disk geometry information to a file

listitem.para: If checked, disk geometry will be printed to a file
If checked, the backup will follow links and copy their targets rather than copying the link into the backup

Selecting this option will run an incremental backup instead of a full one. When using this option, the last complete backup is used and only changes are copied, making the backup much quicker. However, because only changes are copied all older backups are discarded.

important.para: Currently, this option is only available with the rsync on *nix platforms.

listitem.para: Archive (tar engine): The backup is contained within a single .tar archive file making it easy to manage and/or manipulate.

A compressed archive (gzip - tar.gz engine): This engine is identical to the tar engine with the exception that the archive is filtered through a gzip compression filter on-the-fly to result in a smaller file. It is faster than bz2 compression, but also has larger file sizes.

A compressed archive (bz2 - tar.bz2engine): This engine is is identical to the tar engine with the exception that the archive is filtered through a bz2 comrpession filter on-the-fly to result in a smaller file. bz2 is much slower and more CPU-intensive than gzip compression, but tends to result in much lower file sizes.

A copy of the files or folders (rsync engine): The backup is contained within a folder, just as if the files were copied via drag-and-drop. These type of backups can be harder to manage because all the files are loose rather than contained in a single archive. While the rsync engine does not support any form of compression, it does offer incremental backups on *nix-based platforms.
Command(s) entered here will run in the default system shell before &app; begins to backup path.
Command(s) entered here will run in the default system shell after &app; has finished backuping up path.
A newline-separated list of files, folders and/or patterns.

This controls the priority of the backup. A lower nice value indicates a higher priority. Please note this feature is only available on *nix based platforms and only root may set a negative nice value.

sect1.title: Changing your preferences
sect1.para:
To change your preferences, choose
Edit Preferences
. The configurable options available to you are:

listitem.para: Toggling this checkbox will show or hide the tray icon.
If this checkbox is enabled, you will recieve notifications like the one below for important events:

textobject.phrase: A notification in the tray area

listitem.para: Enabling this checkbox will make &app; minimize to the tray icon when closing instead of quitting.

tip.para: Clicking the tray icon will reopen the main &app; window.

listitem.para: Check this box if you would like &app; to only show the tray icon, not the main window when starting.
This option enables all debugging messages in the log viewer. It is not recommended to enable this option unless you are trying to troubleshoot a problem.
This option will start place &app; in the tray area as soon as you login.

When running on the Windows platform, &app; must be configured with the installation folder of the pycron software. The installation folder can generally be auto-detected, but in the event that it isn't use the Browse button to manually choose the folder.

Several messages in &app; can be disabled by selecting "Don't show me again" when they appear. If you would like to enable these messages again, click the
Shows a refresh button. (refresh) button.

glossdef.para: The folder which the backup will be created in.

example.title: Backup Sets
example.para: If a set named Home ran on May 9 2007, engine of tar (archive) and the backup destination was set to /media/Backups, the result would be an archive named Backup-Home-2007-05-09.tar in the folder /media/Backups.

glossdef.para:
The backend for a given backup. Supported engines in this release are:
tar (archive)
tar.gz (archive filtered through gzip compression)
tar.bz2 (archive filtered through bz2 compression)
rsync (direct copy, comparable to a drag-and-drop copy operation in a file browser)

A group of files and/or folders that are backed up periodically at a specified time and date to the set's destination. Sets have their own configuration, meaning the options of one set has no effect on the optiosn of another.
Identical to a backup set, with the exception that one-time backups do not run periodically (it will only run once).

Any task where manipulating files is involved, such as:
Backing up a set
Performing a one-time backup
Restoring a backup
A path what represents a file or folder's location on your computer. /home/myusername, ~/apicture.jpg and C:\Program Files are all examples of valid paths.

tip.para: In the end, path is just really a fancy name for the location of any file or folder. /home/myusername or C:\Program Files are both valid paths because they both point to the spot of a file or folder!
